She was a daugh ter of the late Captain Wilson Hix, of Appomattox, a leader in the community which play ed so dramatic a part in the War Between the States. Her mother was a sister of Hon. Thomas S. Bocock, of Appo mattox, who was the speaker of the House during the brief re gime of the Confederacy. Mrs. Gills remembered vivid ly the circumstances of the sur render of General Lee at Appo mattox. The surrender took place on a farm owned by her rather, and the terms of sur render were drawn and signed in a building formerly owned by her father, who sold it to Major McLean during the war. General Grant took possession of her fathers home for eight days while the Confederate sol diers were being paroled. When the Union soldiers were beginning to evacuate the village, an officer approached the young daughter of the house and informed her that he had hidden away a barrel of flour and a chicken, so that when they were gone her fami ly might not suffer for provi sions. The gloom of war was bright ened for Mrs. Gills by the ro mantic attachment she felt for her first cousin, Daniel Gills, a young cavalrymen in Fitzhughjj Lees brigade, which after the war culminated in marriage. Also, as a further showing of appreciation to t h e s e visitors for coming to Appomattox, they are asking that these rooms be made available without cost. Plans are being made to place centennial housing guest cards in an information center which will be located at a cen tral point on the western e d g e of Appomattc-x, and which will be manned by a member of one of the clubs in Centennial dress to offer guest cards and give out information.
